description:
First, another figure millions thought they knew.

They tried to make me go to rehab, I said no, no, no.

Amy Winehouse, diminutive singer, songwriter with a deep voice who died of alcohol poisoning four years ago this month. Rarely can a 27-year-old's life have been so picked-over by the media, from the 2003 debut album Frank, followed by the international hit Back To Black three years later, winner of five Grammy Awards. But it was the personal life that fascinated so many: her marriage, her addiction to drink and drugs and her consequently often erratic performances. It became something even unpleasant spectator sport: what would she do next? How would she let herself and all that talent down? A couple of years ago, the director Asif Kapadia and producer James Gay-Rees were approached by Amy Winehouse's music company, Universal, with a proposal to make a film. Together with editor Chris King, that team had made a critically acclaimed documentary about the Brazilian Formula One driver Ayrton Senna. Like that film, this mixes archive footage and sound with newly recorded interview.

"We'd recorded quite a few demo recordings, and I started to talk about whether she ever considered writing. She said she's not sure about writing songs, but she's written a lot of poems. She knew full well she'd been writing songs, but they were very personal songs."

Amy Winehouse's first manager Nick Shymansky, much of whose personal footage of the early performances is included in the documentary.
